title: joanna-blythman-palestine-george-floyd-moment-pick-side
story: Something has changed when people who usually post pictures of their breakfast blueberry pancakes are replacing them with statements about Gaza.As busily as many parts of the media frame the carnage in Gaza as ldquoclashesrsquo between two sides of a contextless conflict that has blown up inexplicably, social media swells with themes of Israeli apartheid and state-sanctioned violence.High profile people outwith political circles are speaking out, such as singer Rihanna and actors Gal Gadot, a former Israeli soldier, and Idris Elba. ldquoItrsquos the brutality and bloodshed that has compelled me to raise concern, Elba says.:The real reason your doctor wont see you nowAs they beat Cha to the FA Cup, two Leicester City players held up a Palestine flag, a signicant gesture. Cha owner Roman Abramovich is a funder of settler group Elad, which ldquodisplaces" Palestinians from occupied East Jerusalem. Football legends Paul Pogba and his Manchester United team-mate Amad Diallo flew the Palestinian flag again following their teamrsquos final home game.One week ago today, , people marched through London for Palestine. Itrsquos easier to list the major cities and towns throughout the UK that didnrsquot hold pro-Palestine demonstrations than those that did.This solidarity movement is building worldwide. In Livorno, Italian dockers refused to load cargo onto a ship taking weapons to Israel. In Leicester, protesters staged a vigil on the roof of the Israeli-owned Elbit factory, which makes combat drones.Whatrsquos changed  Palestine is having its George Floyd moment, and Israel no longer controls the narrative. The world is watching the pain of Palestine with horror. ldquoBothsideing doesnrsquot cut it. People who were scared to speak out have decided that staying neutral in the face of brutality is not an ethical option.I visited Palestine in  to meet farmers in the occupied West Bank. Their resilience under the boot of Israeli occupation was extraordinary. We travelled from East Jerusalem, to Ramallah, Nablus, Jericho, and Jenin, and met producers like Taysir Sadia Yaseen who kept growing olives even though  of his familyrsquos , trees had been bulldozed by Israel to make way for a "security buffer zone around an encroaching, illegal settlement.I spoke with women who make the Palestinian speciality, maftoul, similar to couscous. Their families had been living in the UN Ein Al-Sultan refugee camp all the long years since Israel forcibly evicted them from their homes in Tel Aviv and Haa.Itrsquos one thing to use the word ldquooccupation and another to witness it first hand.The spiritual and physical ugliness of Israelrsquos hulking ldquoseparation barrier, the soul-destroying daily rigmarole at checkpoints staffed by sulky Israeli teenage soldiers armed with machine guns.My most chilling experience was queuing in a car with Palestinian number plates at a checkpoint while a band of settlers stood at the roadside screaming abuse and hammering on the car, undisturbed by the checkpoint guards. These settlers looked unhinged and highly volatile. Nowhere have I felt so threatened.Palestinians put up with this ever day of their lives.When I ed from the West Bank I wrote articles for news outlets calling on consumers to boycott Israeli and settlement products, such as Medjoul dates, as part of the global Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions campaign.A Palestinian protesterIt uses the same tactics as the South African anti-apartheid movement.There were letters of complaint but my pieces were published.In more recent years, those articles may not have seen the light of day because the Israeli government, by deliberately conflating all criticism of Israel with antisemitism, had effectively silenced it.The respected Palestinian academic Edward Said nailed it: ldquoFear of speaking out about one of the greatest injustices in modern history has hobbled, blinkered, muzzled many who know the truth and are in a position to serve it.Glasgow University professor of communications and social change Greg Philo quoted an editor who, defending his news operationrsquos attempts to portray the situation as two evenly matched sides in a war, rather than the systematic oppression of a stateless people by one of the worldrsquos most technologically advanced armies, as saying: ldquoWe wait in fear for the telephone call from the Israelis.rsquoBefore the latest Gaza onslaught, we watched the trial-by-media of Jeremy Corbyn, hounded as an anti-semite for sticking up for Palestinians.The idea that he is anti-semitic is preposterous, a monstrous slur. Yet many media outlets joined the witch-hunt lest the bullies added them to its target list.Perhaps now that Israel has razed the tower block that housed the Associated Press and Al Jazeera news agencies, the fourth estate might find the bottle to craft reports around the facts on the ground, not Israeli government spin,only to show support for their fellow journalists.:Joanna Blythman: Its not up to politicians to tell us that we cant hug our loved onesThose facts, as I see them, are as follows.The context is half a century of illegal occupation. The recent violence was provoked by Israeli troops who attacked praying Palestinians in al-Aqsa mosque with tear gas and rubber-coated steel bullets, and the escalation of expulsions of Palestinians from their homes in Sheikh Jarrah, East Jerusalem, in defiance of international law.Since then wersquove seen the usual asymmetric death toll repeat. As I write over  Palestinians have been killed, including  women and  children.  Israelis have been killed, including one child. Since , Israel has killed roughly , Palestinians, more than half of them civilians , were children.The Public International Law Centre rightly condemns the current situation in Gaza as ldquoa scene of historic and current human rights violations, and in some cases, war crimes.There is no moral equivalence here. As with apartheid South Africa, you must pick a side.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: kevin-mckenna-richard-dawkins-got-wrong-people-downs-syndrome
story: The petition I signed last week was organised by the Downrsquos syndrome charity Donrsquot Screen Us Out in response to comments made by the scientist Richard Dawkins in a recent interview with Brendan OrsquoConnor, the Irish radio presenter. During it, Mr OrsquoConnor asks Professor Dawkinshe stands by advice he once offered to a woman who was unsure of the correct course of action in the event of being pregnant with a Downrsquos syndrome baby. The professor had told her: ldquoAbort it and try again. It would be immoral to bring it into the worldyou have a choice.Mr OrsquoConnor declares his interest in this debate from the outset. He has a daughter with Downrsquos syndrome but he maintains a high level of professional detachment throughout the interview and conducts it in a spirit of polite inquiry. What follows from Professor Dawkins is perhaps the bleakest evaluation of humanity yoursquore likely to hear in a modern setting. What adds to the chill factor, I think, is that it also prescribes an inevitable direction of travel when the state presumes to legislate on matters surrounding end-of-le care.: English Tory triumph means that independence is our last refuge, by Kevin McKennaThe professor partially retreats from his original opinion by withdrawing the term lsquoimmoralrsquo. He suggests rather that it would be ldquowise and sensible in such circumstances to opt for an abortion. His justication for this is his assertion that ldquothe amount of suffering in the world probably does not go down ndash probably goes up ndash compared to having another child who doesnrsquot have Downrsquos syndrome. Professor Dawkins, a biologist who appeals to scientic fact during his regular trolling of people who profess religious faith, admits his view about what constitutes lsquosufferingrsquo is evidence-free. ldquoIt seems to me to be plausible I have no direct evidence, he tells the interviewer when pressed.Wersquoll leave aside the issue of how much an affluent white man residing in a rich country can ever fully grasp the concept of human suffering and its effects. These happy accidents of birth and the advantages they have bestowed on Mr Dawkins means he will always be inoculated from the suffering of multitudes of other humans less favoured. As a gted biologist the professor has used his advantages well in advancing our understanding of ourselves and the world we inhabit. Inexplicably though, the knowledge he has gathered about the beautul ersity of creation seems not to have increased his compassion for it, but soiled it. What he is professing amounts to eugenics: the belief that only the fittest or best-equipped among us deserve to experience quality in our lives.Here, I must declare my own interest in this issue: I have a niece with Downrsquos syndrome. Itrsquos impossible to convey in a column such as this how much hurt she would feel, knowing that another human being harboured thoughts such as these how reduced how unloved how devalued. Ciara is a young woman now and, having known only the love of a large extended family, is embarking on a journey into adulthood and a future that holds the promise of good things.She has already represented her country in ious sports and, thanks to the skills, dedication and compassion of her primary school teachersshe is living a full le. She is also contributing to the happiness of others, this being a basic requirement for peaceful co-existence on earth. Professor Dawkins in his cruel, arrogant ignorance believes she and millions of others with Downrsquos syndrome are incapable of such. And lacking any evidence he chooses to see only that which he regards as other and abnormal and that these must be feared ndash and thus destroyed. It is the philosophy of Salem.Richard DawkinsYou hesitate to sign an entreaty that might adversely affect anotherrsquos ability to earn their keep. The Donrsquot Screen Us Out petition though, leaves room for Professor Dawkins to reconsider his views and their consequences for humanitythey ever entered the mainstream. It says this: ldquoPenguin Random House publishes Richard Dawkinsrsquo books. As a company, they make it clear that they ldquocelebrate and actively promote ersity and inclusion in all its forms, including and not limited to the nine protected characteristics cited in The Equality Act  including ldquodisability. They go on to say that ldquoIt is not acceptable to make dismissive or hostile remarks about a person on any basis or to make assumptions about someonersquos lestyle, interests or abilities.You may be tempted to dismiss criticism of the professor on the basis that, as a high-profile atheist they are consistent with a view that there is no ultimate force for good and that we must simply let the dice roll as they please. lsquoMoralityrsquo being merely existential, this is a grand space to inhabit in which you can set your own boundaries on what you consider to be lsquogoodrsquo. It conveniently frees us from any moral obligation to make the world lsquobetterrsquo.:Downs children like my beautul niece Ciara are a gt ndash not a burdenYet, itrsquos not on the basis of uncertain and precarious religious faith that we must disdain Professor Dawkinsrsquo barren evaluation of humanity. None of us was born complete. We will never be the finished article. At some point in our lives we will require to be fixed and restored. On these occasions the healing can only be provided by others and rests on their willingness to give something of themselves while asking nothing in .For many, the brokenness is long-lasting or permanent and may never be healed. This will call for an extraordinary measure of unconditional devotion that resists the urge to calculate cost or predict benefits. Itrsquos perhaps the most perfect love of all, but itrsquos one which we all have the capacity to offer. Richard Dawkins possesses it too and Irsquom sad that he under-estimates his own ability to reach it.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: deck-downton-abbey-meets-game-thrones
story: Or, as one story in Tatler puts it, ldquoa wave of affluent buyers looking to escape lockdown misery snap up their own floating palaces. How the other half live, eh My fascination with motor yachts, though, is largely stoked by the fact I have been binge-watching a reality TV series called Below Deck. The show follows a motley yacht crew as they toil at the beck-and-call of uber-rich clients with eye-watering demands.It is not for the faint-hearted, with the premise best described as Downton Abbey meets Keeping Up With The Kardashians with a dash of Game of Thrones.After each charter,all goes well, the staff below stairs get a huge tip from the guests ndash then swtly splash this hard-earned cash by getting legless at swanky beach and island resorts dotted across the Caribbean and Mediterranean.There are drunken spats and messy dramas and simmering feuds and dastardly power plays that will make you gasp at their audacity. It is terribly gauche yet gloriously compelling viewing.:Susan Swarbrickrsquos Week: A semblance of normality looms ndash why donrsquot I feel ready I say this because I have devoured  episodes of Below Deck Mediterranean. I am now three series into Below Deck .Mastermind, here I come. My specialist subject: the trials and tribulations of chief stewardesses Kate Chastain and Hannah Ferrier on Below Deck. These women embody ingenuity and tenacity. They are nails.To be honest, Irsquove always envied those with the robust constitution that makes a good sailor. Over the years, I have been seasick on the Atlantic, Pacic and Indian oceans, as well as the Adriatic, Coral, South China, Red, North, Mediterranean and Tasman seas. It is hard to choose my most embarrassing debacle in this vein.Arguably, it is a toss-up between when I became queasy on a pedalo on Loch Lomond and had to be towed to shore as small children pointed in horried amusement as my pallor veered between ghostly grey and pistachio green.Or perhaps the shark-ing excursion in South Africa where I misjudged the direction of the wind and inadvertently acquainted a poor German chap dozing on the deck with the remnants of my breakfast.To this day, I still marvel at how calm and polite he was ndash even when the smell from his soggy fleece pervaded the minibus all the way back to Cape Town.:Susan Swarbricks Week: Help! I have a serious dose of vaccine envyI have crossed the North Atlantic on QE during a force  storm, a torrid experience that saw me spend the best part of two days hugging the toilet in my cabin like I was Kate Winslet clinging to that floating shard of wood in the film Titanic.So, the question remains: would I buy a big fancy boat. Probably not. But you donrsquot need sea legs to dream on the sofa.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: pearlfishers-larks---scotlands-favourite-albums
story: WHEN I walked out of Shibuya Station in Tokyo for the first time, itrsquos no exaggeration to say the sight facing me was mind blowing. I felt like I was swimming against a tide of humanity as , commuters surged towards me.In , as a naiumlve tourist, I had no idea that the area ndash known as Shibuya Scramble Crossing ndash was the worldrsquos busiest pedestrian intersection.The zigzag pattern of zebra markings dissecting the vast traffic junction should have been a dead giveaway.Five years later, Davie Scott of The Pearlfishers, had an identical heart-stopping experience to mine. His was made even more daunting by the pouring rain. Scott was so moved by what he saw that he wrote The Umbrellas Of Shibuya, a stunning song which helped colour the album he now regards as a career high.ldquoI was doing an acoustic tour of Japan along with Duglas T. Stewart of The BMX Bandits, said Scott.:Hue And Cry: Remote. Scotlands favourite albumsldquoIn Shibuya Station we both looked out over the plaza. It was raining and there were thousands of people carrying multi-coloured plastic umbrellas on the crossing. I was overwhelmed by the visual beauty of what was in front of me. It had a profound effect.ldquoThe tour also coincided with a particularly happy period in my le.ldquoSo writing the song became an exercise in saying: lsquoWhat does this visual image mean to me rsquoldquoTherersquos a line in the lyric where I sing: lsquoDuglas, just thinkwe could bottle each drop of this feathered rainrsquo. Irsquom talking to him in the song.ldquoWhen I recorded the track, sonically it was really saying: lsquoHow do you portray the extraordinary beauty that is Tokyo hellip or any part of Japan rsquoldquoIrsquove never forgotten it. The song is my love letter to the country itself.Itrsquos a key track on Up With The Larks ndash released on German label, Marina Records ndash which is a musical masterpiece of evocative lyrics and beautul melodies.Scott has made no secret of his passion for writers such as Paul McCartney, Brian Wilson and Jimmy Webb. Their craft is reflected in his own. The album was recorded in a studio at East Kilbride Arts Centre. The catalyst for the record was when Scott took part in Burnsong ndash a creative workshop staged in Croys, a country house in Castle Douglas ndash where a group of musicians were put together to write with each other for the first time.:Lloyd Cole, Madness, Eighties pop: A Week in RadioldquoIrsquod never done very much co-writing up until that point, he revealed.ldquoBut I really enjoyed it and wrote a bunch of songs I liked. Although none of them actually ended up on the album, I really got into a flow and from that point on the songs were coming steadily. Some of the energy for the album came from that event.Scott already had an impressive musical track record. Between -, hersquod released six albums and toured the UK.His seventh record, Up With The Larks, evolved during a particularly fertile period.ldquoThe songs on the record are probably the best Irsquove ever written, he said.ldquoThey came at a time when I was busy on several dferent projects. But in the studio, I had vocal mics plus the piano and a drum kit set up permanently. SoI ever wanted to work on a new song, I literally just had to press lsquoPlayrsquo and lsquoRecordrsquo.As ever, his lyrics were flavoured by experience. The first batch of songs included The Bluebells, Eco Schools, Londonrsquos In Love and Blue Riders On The Range. ldquoThe Bluebells was the first big song. Itrsquos a love song for my we Margaret, revealed Davie.:Billy Sloan: Associatesrsquo ground-breaking debut was both baffling and beguilingldquoItrsquos about perpetual love hellip so it almost wrote itself. When I had that, I thought, this is something worth building on.ldquoIrsquod also had a letter from a local primary school asking me to come and talk to the kids about having a career in the music business. It was an eco-school, where they had a real dedication to the environment, with an eco-council and eco-warriors, who do sustainable work. That also led to a song.Blue Riders On The Range ndash one of my favourite tracks on the album ndash channels the influence of Brian Wilson, and in particular, Paul McCartney.ldquoI was sitting at the piano improvising some chord ideas, and suddenly I got little bits I could work with hellip almost like doing a sculpture, he recalled.ldquoThe song came from a feeling of trying to escape your everyday le and find something magical. Itrsquos that whole Brian Wilson approach. But,there is a real sonic template for the track, itrsquos more Paul McCartneyrsquos  album, Ram. When I hear that song itrsquos really me trying to do Ram.Itrsquos also one of four songs on the record produced by Scottrsquos close friend, Norman Blake of Teenage Fanclub.:Orange Juice: The Glasgow School: Released ndash . Scotlands favourite albums by Billy SloanldquoI wanted something a little bit dferent in the production process, so I asked Norman to work on a few tracks, he said. ldquoWe just clicked, as we always have done. Therersquos a real bond. The thing that probably turned it into the song it is hellip is that big, but very simple chorus of three chords and four words, where I sing lsquoGet on a feeling Get on a feelingrsquo.ldquoNorman was responsible for the extra choruses at the end. Irsquod had the song quite tight until he said: lsquoYoursquove GOT to repeat that chorusrsquo.ldquoHe wanted to hear it again and again. Norman was a real big part of those tracks. Even just down to the feeling in the room. Other key songs include the autobiographical, Fighting Fire With Flowers. Scott said: ldquoThere are three verses in that song. The first is about something that happened at school when I got into a fight. The second is about my teenage years sitting in The Bouled Cafeacute in Falkirk hellip and the third is more of a widescreen look at the way the world is always at war.Plus the sublime soul of Womack And Womack and I Just See The Rainbow, in which he composed a song for the late Karen Carpenter. ldquoIn my head, I was thinking of her voice hellip I was writing it for her, revealed Scott.ldquoShe was obviously lone gone by then. Butyou listen to the song, just imagine that itrsquos Karen Carpenter who is singing it. When I recorded my vocal I was so focused on that. I donrsquot sound anything like her, but it does have a certain softness about it which was almost like me putting myself into a character.Up With The Larks was well received by both critics and fans alike. Scott has released a further two albums since then and is working on a new record scheduled for later in . He is also currently the Head of Arts and Media at the University of the West Of Scotland.Like all songwriters, he is optimistic that his best song has always got to be his next song. But he has a special affection for Up With The Larks as an accomplished body of work.Scott said:ldquoIrsquom now old enough to know that your existence doesnrsquot necessarily rest on your best work being ahead of you. Irsquom making a new record at the moment and think the songs on it are great. Naturally, you want it to be a brilliant album. Butit turns out not to be as good as Up With The Larks, I wonrsquot cry because I know just how good that music is.ldquoItrsquos a very musical record hellip very melodic. The arrangements are super intricate. I didnrsquot used to think of it as being a particularly lyrical record. But talking about it now, I can see therersquos loads of stuff that is very personal.However, the albumrsquos continued success has given Scott an on-going problem. When The Pearlfishers play live, hersquos got to cherry pick which tracks to perform hellip such is the sheer volume of his back catalogue of songs.ldquoBear in mind that Irsquove now been making records for  years, so you kind of have an overview of what yoursquove done, he said finally.ldquoI can look at every album Irsquove made and feel happy with them. Irsquove enjoyed writing and recording them all hellip and each has got things that I love.ldquoBut Up With The Larks is the album I keep going back to.THE Billy Sloan Show is on BBC Radio Scotland every Saturday at pm.MAKING HISTORYDAVIE Scott of The Pearlfishers has created his music in some of the worldrsquos most famous recording studios. His songs have taken him to the hallowed ground of Abbey Road, where he followed in the footsteps of his hero Paul McCartney. He also worked on albums in live rooms where Pink Floyd and The Who made pop history.But in a -year music career, Scott has made a little bit of magic of his own, in a home-grown studio which wasnrsquot a recording facility at all. He was the in-house producer, composer and general facilitator at East Kilbride Arts Centre.ldquoIt was a medium sized office that I set up to record in, recalled Davie. ldquoIt didnrsquot even have a control room and was very primitive. But we had good microphones, instruments and a piano I borrowed from the Village Theatre. So all the actual equipment to make great records was there.Scott recorded many of The Pearlfishersrsquo albums in the tiny studio. He worked there with Ricky Ross of Deacon Blue, The BMX Bandits, The Pastels and members of Teenage Fanclub.Legendary US acts Alex Chilton, Chip Taylor, Evie Sands and Kim Fowley also made records in the unlikely setting of a converted office in East Kilbride.ldquoThink of a classic album like Sgt. Pepperrsquos hellip it sounds really epic, said Davie.ldquoBut it was made by lashing a couple of four-track recorders together. The point is to get the songs and arrangements right, and then make sure itrsquos recorded pretty faithfully. You can do that anywhere.ldquoWe recorded very simply. There was no monkey business. It was a makesht studio, but it lasted for  very successful years. We produced a ton of great records there.For Up With The Larks, Scott decided to give the album sleeve ndash a series of childlike drawings of birds ndash a real personal flavour.ldquoI made the artwork under the name of Oscar In Venice, revealed Davie.ldquoStefan Kassell, the designer at Marina Records, took these little scraps of paper I had ndash felt pen drawings ndash and organised them into this brilliant album package.ldquoTherersquos also a lovely wee postscript to the story. I was contacted by the producer of the hit American TV drama, Veronica Mars. He was a fan of the band and commissioned a full size painting of the front cover which I had shipped over to Los Angeles. It sits in his house to this day.

title: sir-walter-scott-scottish-icons-rab-mcneil
story: man of parts.Best known as a writer, he is also accused of having been active in the legal profession, as an advocate, Clerk of Session, and Sherf-Depute of Selkirkshire, valuable work that interests nobody.Created a baronet in , he organised the groundbreaking visit of George IV to Edinburgh in .Hersquos said to have ldquoinvented Scotland, or at least its public image which, letrsquos face it, is a facade.He first showed his coupon to the world on  August , when he was born up a wynd in Edinburgh. He was one of nine children . Donrsquot let that give the impression the family was poor. Back then, posh and pauper lived cheek by jowl, at least in the centre of the smelly old city.:It took  years to build the Wall. Their tradesmen were even worse than ours Rab McNeils Scottish IconsScottrsquos father was a lawyer claiming descent from Clan Scott, while his mother, a physicianrsquos daughter, traced her lot to Clan Swinton. Childhood polio left him lame, which saw him sent to the Borders for a cure. Instead he found a vocation: Aunty Jenny taught him to read.After schooling at Edinburghrsquos Royal High and Kelso Grammar, he attended Edinburgh University at the age of  to study classics and, at , began a legal apprenticeship. At , he became Prime Minister and, at , walked on the surface of the Moon. Only joking but, given the pace of his le story so far, it wouldnrsquot be surprising.As for literature, he first took a fancy to German poems, which he translated for publication. The Germans at that time were interested in folk culturewhich sparked Scottrsquos interest in traditional Border ballads.Before long, Scott himself became the most popular poet in the land, starting with his The Lay of the Last Minstrel, published in . Yersquoll ken these famous lines from the last stanza: ldquoBreathes there a man, with soul so dead Who never to himself hath said This is my own, my native land!Well, yes, there does: see letters page some weeks.His Marmion, a racytale of lust, duels, folk walled up in nunneries, and the Battle of Flodden, also features the famous line: ldquoO what a tangled web we weave When first we practise to deceive.That was published in , by which time he was a right Tory. That same year, he cancelled his subscription to the Edinburgh Review when it advocated peace with Napoleon.:Billy Connolly: lsquoIrsquom the only guy I know who died in a f*****g Muppet moviersquoWaverley, the first of his  novels, was a great success and, despite writing anonymously , everyone knew who he was, and succeeding works would be by ldquothe author of Waverley and so forth.He was massively popular, the Dan Brown of his day. His novels dealt with historical themes, often set in Scotland ndash including Guy Mannering, Redgauntlet, Rob Roy ndash and sometimes in Englandshire, including Ivanhoe, Kenilworth, The Fortunes of Nigel, Peveril of the Peak.Their themes were ious, though one at least could be renamed Nigelrsquos Overdue Mortgage. For the avoidance of doubt, Heart of Midlothian isnrsquot about football, and the short story Wandering Williersquos Taledoesnrsquot concern a sex pest.A major theme is the romantic enchantment of the Jacobite cause, but Scott believed that time was over. He accepted Hanoverian rule. His stance on the national question is occasionally described as ambiguous , but he was a supporter of the Union who sometimes sounded otherwise in his work.However, it never does to confuse a writer and his characters who often, we should note, spoke with a strong Scots brogue, at leastthey were lower class.Scott played a major part in cementing Scotlandrsquos place in the United Kingdom when, in , he organised the pageantry for the visit of King George IV, a debauched lard-bucket, to Scotland. The event saw the ultimate rehabilitation of Highland society, after the previous centuryrsquos Jacobite recalcitrance.:Itrsquos haddock for Humphrey as jakeys neck cans on the pierKing Dod wore a kilt, which habiliment subsequently became popular . The Lowlands compromised with tartan trews, arguably the most hideous habiliment in the history of trousers.If all this sounds like a never-ending success story, disaster struck Scott with the collapse in  of the Ballantyne publishing business, in which he had the sole financial interest. He was ruined. He endeavoured to write himself out of his dire situation, but after a few years his health began to fail, and he died of a stroke at his Borders pile, Abbotsford, on  September . With his books still selling, his estate was cleared of debt after his death.Scott is not an easy read today. In , a columnist on the New York Herald asked: ldquoWho has not read the Pirate  In , a foreword to the novel answered with melancholy honesty: ldquoVirtually everyone. Sentences meander like the Tweed, and the language is lofty. Opening my copy of Ivanhoe at random, I find: ldquolsquoBy my troth,rsquo said the knight, lsquothou has sung well and lustily, and in high praise of thine order.rsquoldquolsquoWhit rsquo said the hermit.I made the second bit up. A bookmark tells me I reached page  out of  of The Pirate. My fault rather than Scottrsquos: I probably started reading a Dan Brown instead.:Sir Alex Ferguson ndash Scottish Icon, by Rab McNeilOn a more positive note, the Encyclopedia Britannica describes Scott appreciatively as ldquothe master of a rich, ornate, seemingly effortless literary style that blended energy with decorum, lyric beauty with clarity of description.This is true, though it still might seem stodgy to us. Times and tastes change .Sir Walter Scott changed the face of fiction. But, as well as a man of letters, we remember him as a man of selfless endeavour and prodigious civic commitment.

title: together-electric-dreams-classic-cars-converted-suit-modern-drivers
story: Built in a year of petrol rationing due to the Suez crisis, when tales of Russian spies gripped the nation, and the Ecurie Ecosse team took the chequered flag at Le Mans, the cc model has aged remarkably well since it rolled off the production line exactly  years ago.Since  itrsquos clocked up tens of thousands of miles ndash but exactly how many is hard to tell, as there are only five digits on the mileometer. And yet as it sets off, therersquos not even the slightest puff of exhaust to be seen belching from its back end.Classic car on the outside, under the bonnet the Morris Minor has undergone an electrying revamp to bring it up to speed for a new, greener age.Having converted the classic car from petrol to electric battery ndash and upped its top speed from mph to mph in the process ndash Wayne and son Euan are now tearing out the environmentally unfriendly innards of a  T VW Campervan.Eventually, it will be fitted with a very modern kW Tesla battery pack and Tesla Drive Unit, giving it a range of up to  miles and turning it from gas guzzler and emission heavy to a clean machine.For some fans of classic cars, ripping out roaring petrol engines in favour of deathly silent electric, is nothing short of sacrilege.Yet for what appears to be an increasing number of classic car enthusiasts, swapping the unreliability of a well-used combustion engine for a thoroughly modern alternative under the bonnet, is the only way to travel.Waynersquos Electron Garage in Fe is believed to be the only one of its kind in Scotland currently converting classic vehicles to electric.However, a handful of specialist garages have already sprouted in England and Wales, and turned classic cars like Triumph Stags, Porsche  Coupes, E-type Jaguars, VW Beetles, Campervans and Morgans ndash and even one lsquoBack to the Futurersquo DeLorean ndash into all-electric vehicles.Celebrities have already led the way: singer Ellie Goulding rolled up to her  wedding in a VW Campervan which had been converted to use a Tesla engine and battery, and Slumdog Millionaire actor Dev Patel had his Fiat  converted to electric.While the Duke and Duchess of Sussex drove into their wedding reception in a pound, converted -year-old E-Type Jaguar.Wayne concedes not everyone is a fan of tinkering with classics. But as more classics are converted, the more we are likely to see vehicles from days gone by on our roads.ldquoThere are two camps out there, says Wayne. ldquoOne says we shouldnrsquot do this to a classic vehicle ndash and there are some cars we would not want to touch.ldquoBut there are also a lot of classic cars sitting in garages and barns that donrsquot turn a wheel from year to year because they are dficult cars to live with.ldquoWith a lot of older cars, you need a toolkit with you whenever you go for a drive. They break down and yoursquore left at the side of the road.ldquoElectrying it gives it a new lease of le, and helps it keep going for another  or  years. You can drive it without worrying about it getting you to where you want to go.Government plans to crackdown on heavy emission diesel and petrol cars, plus the prospect of low emission zones in city centres is driving some owners to rethink how they power their classic car in the future.While the combination of eco-conscious millennials with a hankering for retro design, and older lsquopetrolheadsrsquo seeking to revisit the cars of their youth and, perhaps reluctantly, accepting their emissions are less than friendly, are also said to be fuelling the trend.In the case of the Morris Minor, the engine, fuel tank and ious other original components were removed and replaced by an electric engine and Kw battery packs from a Nissan Leaf written off by insurers following a smash.Inserting the new technology into the old car was far from straight-forward, with parts salvaged from other cars and even a motorbike used to help merge the old with new.The sheer challenge of trying to squeeze the new components into a tiny engine and boot space was tricky: in the end not all of the battery pack would fit.It means the range is limited to only around  miles ndash but, adds Wayne, enough for a city car.At Car Cave Scotland in Bonnyrigg, Midlothian, Alan Potts specialises in selling classic cars to enthusiasts ndash and business is booming.Few, he thinks, would want to trade the roar of a classic engine for the soft whirr of an electric motor.ldquoThe general consensus of opinion among classic car guys is that yoursquod be ruining your classic car, he says.ldquoIf you have a Morris Minor or an MG Mgb Gt thatrsquos worth maybe pound to pound, and you then convert it, yoursquoll affect the value of the car a little but not massively.ldquoBut convert an E-type Jaguar to electric and yoursquoll really affect the value of the car.ldquoAnd with some old cars like, say, an Aston Martin, the noise they make is everything, he continues. ldquoTo switch on the engine and all of a sudden therersquos a whizzing noise hellip it kicks the guts out of the car a little bit.But electric is the future: the Scottish Government has set a target of  to phase out the need for new petrol and diesel cars and vans, as part of its ambitions to slash emissions by % by , and to net-zero by .It has also introduced subsidies to help motorists purchase electric vehicles, tax relief for drivers of low-emission vehicles and invested pound. million in supporting the uptake of electric vehicles.Nevertheless, Alan says demand for retro petrol classics ndash particularly old favourites of the Seventies and Eighties which he imports from South Africa - is soaring.ldquoThere is massive demand, he says. ldquoWe sht about  classic Fords every monthwe had more of certain models, wersquod sht even more.ldquoMost popular are Escort Mark  and , Capris, Cortinas. Then therersquos the generation that wants XRs and XRS Turbos which are quite popular.ldquoPeople want the car they wanted when they were young - there are a lot of guys aged  and  who are buying cars they remember they father drove.ldquoIn the case of the Ford Granada, guys used to banger race them and destroy them. Now they are getting nostalgic for these old cars.ldquoYes, the emissions for some are quite horrendous, but theyrsquore not on the road that much, adds Alan, who sells cars across the UK, and often exports to countries as far afield as Canada, the Czech Republic and even New Zealand.ldquoI like old cars, he adds, ldquoI like to go home with oily hands. If you put an electric engine in, yoursquore ripping the heart of them. ldquo In Glenrothes, the VW Campervan is undergoing its pound, conversion to electric. ldquoWersquove had a lot of enquiries, including for an old Land Rover to be converted, Wayne adds.ldquoPeople have taken cars and customised them for years ndash itrsquos no dferent.ldquoI think interest in converting classic cars to electric will grow as people become more aware of what can be done.

title: iain-macwhirter-time-cancel-university-bosses-violate-laws-free-speech
story: The no-ing of gender-critical feminists and other non-conforming speakers by student unions is bad enough. No-one is actually harmed by this proto-censorship, apart from the students depriving themselves of the opportunity to learn. But things have taken a truly sinister turn in recent weeks.The lives of students like Lisa Keogh at Abertay, and lecturers like Dr Neil Thin at Edinburgh, are being destroyed by crack-handed inquisitions applying Monty Python concepts of justice. Lisa Keoghrsquos advocate, Joanna Cherry MP, has rightly condemned Abertayrsquos violation of the European Convention on Human Rights.:Michael Settle: The reinvention of Project Fear - but will it be a winning combination Highly-paid university principals should now be held to account for failing to defend free speech. Ms Keoghrsquos only crime was to express a wholly-respectable opinion in a debate. She insisted that ldquowomen have vaginas ndash an observation that is only a heresy to advocates of non-binary dogma.Dr Neil Thin was suspended from his role as a senior lecturer in anthropology for criticising the risible decision by Edinburgh University last year to ldquocancel Scotlandrsquos greatest philosopher by striking his name from the David Hume Tower. This for a footnote to an article in  that was disparaging about non-white races.Dr Thin was echoing the views of Scotlandrsquos leading historian, Sir Tom Devine. As former Rector of Edinburgh University I also expressed my dismay at this stupefying act of intellectual philistinism, which has made Edinburgh University an international joke. They had been intending to rename it ldquoJulius Nyerere Tower until someone pointed out that the late president of Tanzania was a homophobe as well as a dictator.I pointed out that its new official name, ldquo George Square, celebrates King George , an ardent imperialist who was responsible for an unprecedented expansion of British colonialism. But they didnrsquot get it.Many academics were horried at the Hume Tower affair, but they kept silent, terried of culture warrior retribution. Dr Thin also had the temerity to question whether a campus event called ldquoResisting Whiteness, which involved people of colour only, didnrsquot look just a bit like ldquosegregation. This elicited howls of protest at his ldquoracism.Any self-respecting institution of higher learning would dismiss such accusations as ridiculous. But principal Peter Mathieson suspended Dr Thin, following claims by students that his remarks were ldquoproblematic and ldquooffensive.What he should have done was censure the students who had called Dr Thin a racist, when he is clearly nothing of the sort. I have looked at the social media comments made by Dr Thin, and none of them could be regarded by any reasonable person as expressing racism. He said what any open-minded person would say about an event which was quite literally segregated on the basis of race. His support for Sir Tom Devine is what every self-respecting academic should have done.I donrsquot particularly blame the students of BlackED for mounting a daft, attention-seeking campaign. Thatrsquos what students do. But I do blame the university authorities for responding to it and validating what was in reality a campaign of intimidation and abuse against a member of staff. These extreme anti-colonialist and non-binary dogmas are usually referred to as ldquowoke, but they would be more accurately described as the sleep of reason. Universities are supposed to challenge dogmas and subject political ideas to rigorous criticism. Yet the university authorities seem to be falling over themselves to encourage these infant Robespierres with their empty slogans and pseudo-scientic jargon.:SNP urge Scottish Secretary to fight back or resign over Australia trade dealOver at Abertay University, principal Nigel Seaton last week defended his decision to conduct a disciplinary investigation into -year-old-mature law student Lisa Keogh for saying that ldquowomen have vaginas. This was in a debate where she was invited to state how she defined ldquowoman. She said that, in her opinion, it was essentially based on biology and a womanrsquos reproductive physiology. She also said that ldquomen are stronger than women on account of their sex, and that male-bodied transwomen should not be competing in womenrsquos sporting events. These are views that would be endorsed by the vast majority of adults, and indeed by Americarsquos leading transgender advocate, Caitlyn Jenner.Abertayrsquos response should have been to dismiss objections to her expressing these opinions in open debate. Yet, principal Seaton has authorised a disciplinary investigation into Lisa Keogh, threatening her with expulsion on the grounds that her views may be ldquooffensive and ldquodiscriminatory.:NEIL MACKAYS BIG READ: It was like Lord of the Flies - Horric accounts of abuse could be boarding schoolsrsquo lsquoMeToorsquo momentHe appears to believe that the university is under a legal obligation under equalities legislation to investigate complaints about comments that supposedly violate the protected characteristic of ldquogender reassignment.Principal Seaton is wrong. Equalities legislation does nothing of the sort. In fact, it upholds Lisa Keoghrsquos right to express her gender-critical opinion. This was made absolutely clear last month by Baroness Falkner, the new chair of the Equality and Human Rights Commission. The views of feminists like Lisa Keogh are in no way discriminatory or hate speech. She said that it is ldquoentirely reasonable to believe that women are defined by their sex and no-one should be ldquopenalised or abused for saying so. ldquoSomeone can believe that people who self-identy as a dferent sex are not the dferent sex that they self-identy, she said.Arguably, it should be Abertayrsquos principal under investigation for conniving in this witch-hunt. In a dignied and restrained interview on BBC Womanrsquos Hour last week, Ms Keogh, a mother of two, explained the distress shersquod suffered being forced to defend herself against this Kafkaesque inquisition. In the midst of sitting her law exams she has had the threat of expulsion hanging over her. Not to mention the abuse she has received from student activists calling her ldquoa typical, cis white woman and much worse.These misguided and unlawful actions by university principals are creating a hostile environment in Scotlandrsquos universities. It extends far beyond Edinburgh and Abertay.The threat of sanctions or stressful disciplinary procedures is chilling debate and making lecturers hesitate to discuss controversial issues. Yet this is precisely what any university teacher should be doing. As for research,academics are looking over their shoulders at Twitter, nothing truly original will ever get done. Just a lot of advocacy research designed to confirm whatever prejudices are acceptable on social media.If universities do not enforce freedom of speech and opinion they cannot perform their proper . Scottish taxpayers expect them to do teaching and research ndash not pursue vendettas against wrongthink. Taxpayer-remunerated principals like Peter Mathieson, earning twice the Prime Ministerrsquos salary, are violating their own university charters, which uphold academic freedom and also free speech provisions of international conventions like the ECHR.:Heralds Higher Education Awards: Hard work and dedication pays off for finalistsNor do university bosses, minds addled by culture war, realise the reputational damage these cases are inflicting on their institutions. Edinburgh University used to get rectors like myself to schmooze rich, potential donors and wealthy American parents willing to pay exorbitant fees. Irsquod now be inclined to tell them to keep their money, and stop funding hate.

title: david-pratt-world-time-rough-trading-myanmar-style
story: Itrsquos an age-old dilemma when imposing sanctions on an authoritarian regime. Just how do you hurt a military junta while ensuring that the people it oppresses are not hurt too Itrsquos over  days now since the February  coup in Myanmar when the army under Senior General Min Aung Hlaing seized power, overthrowing and detaining the elected civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi.Since then, given the widespread protests and brutal crackdown by the regime alongside calls for international sanctions and boycott campaigns, Myanmar has been both a chaotic place to do business and posed an ethical challenge for foreign companies with links to the country.In few other sectors has this been more apparent than in the countryrsquos garments industry. The announcement then last week by international clothing companies including HM and Primark saying they have resumed placing orders with suppliers in Myanmar for the first time following the coup has once again thrown the spotlight on what qualies as ethical trading and due diligence over human rights and supply chains.Both the UK and Swedish companies were among those that suspended orders from the south-east Asian country because of human rights concerns and civil unrest. This is a country where nearly half a million people are employed in factories producing textiles for retailers that also include, among many others, Gap, Next, Adidasand Zara.Shortly after the military seized power, HM was among the  foreign investors in Myanmar who signed a statement committing to the country and employees there during developments of ldquodeep concern. Subsequently, HM said it had been shocked ldquoby the use of deadly force against protesters in Myanmar.lsquoNo direct linksrsquoAS the worldrsquos second-biggest fashion retailer, HM has more than , people relying on jobs at its textile hubs and says its decision now to resume placing orders is based on both concern over job losses and making good on commitments to its Myanmar suppliers. After due diligence, HM has now concluded that as a company it has no direct links with the military in Myanmar.ldquoWe are now looking for legal guidance on how to handle any potential indirect links international companies may have, the retailer assured.ldquoWith our decision we want to avoid the imminent risk of our suppliers having to close their factories which would inevitably result in unemployment for tens of thousands of garment workers, the Swedish company explained.In turn, Primark said it was committed to honouring its existing orders from its Myanmar suppliers ldquohowever long they take to fulfil, adding that it had ldquorecommenced placing some orders with our key strategic suppliers in the country.But as the Financial Times last week pointed out, CA, the Belgian-German-Dutch chain of fast-fashion retail stores, has adopted a dferent stance, telling its suppliers that ldquowe are at this point ndashunless we see signicant improvements within the country ndash not placing any new orders.And so once again, as with other similar global crises in the past, in Myanmar today the question of just how corporate groups should respond to such challenges remains a subject of some industry debate.For those foreign companies operating in the country their presence has long been a juggle between high risk and potential high reward. After half a century of military rule, the opening up of one of Asiarsquos last frontier markets in  led to a surge in foreign direct investment.Huge investmentIN the specic case of Myanmarrsquos garments and apparel industry, foreign investment has surged over the past decade as economic reforms and an end to Western sanctions and trade deals helped establish the sector as the greatest symbol of its nascent emergence as a manufacturing hub.Myanmar garment shipments rose from less than  billion in , about  per cent of exports, to more than .bn in , about % of exports, according to UN Comtrade data.The first blow to this increasingly lucrative sector came with the coronavirus pandemic which as it plunged the world into recession, choked consumer demand, resulting in tens of thousands of lost garment factory jobs in Myanmar and where in Asia.But Myanmarrsquos garment industry was then hit with another blow in the shape of the coup. Since then, it has been workers and trade union leaders, many from within the garment sector, who have played a leading role in organising protests against the military junta.As international condemnation of the coup and the crackdown against these protests grew, European and US fashion brands, among them HM, Primark, Next and Italyrsquos Benetton, began to express through statements their respective positions and stances.While HM and Primark initially simply halted orders, Next said it would split its orders previously going to Myanmar between Bangladesh, Cambodia and China, while Benetton said it would mainly move business to China.ldquoThey donrsquot want to abandon Myanmar ... but itrsquos being forced upon them, said Peter McAllister of Ethical Trade Initiative , a labour rights organisation whose members include European high-street brands.Speaking to Reuters Business News last month, McAllister said that it would be very dficult for Myanmarrsquos garment sector to recoverChinese investors left, given that its estimated Chinese nationals fund nearly one-third of Myanmarrsquos  garment factories, according to the Myanmar Garment Manufacturers Association. That would make the Chinese by far the largest investor group.And therein lies the real problem given that a few Chinese-financed garment factories have in some instances found themselves razed to the ground as anti- Chinese sentiment grew along with the belief that Beijing was supplying, directing and on the international stage diplomatically defending Aung Hlaingrsquos regime.But this still begs the question: why would people who earn their living from these factories want to burn them down Nick Vyas, an associate professor at the University of Southern Calornia and an expert in end-to-end global supply chain management, believes some protesters see such factories as obstacles to the type of change they want.ldquoThe entire protest in Myanmar is led by the people and a big chunk of this group thatrsquos leading this protest, the ones who donrsquot want to go back to the past and live under the dictatorial military rule, are the people working in the garment factories, Vyas explained in an interview with Insider, the financial global news portal.ldquoThese people are working six days a week, sometimes seven days a week, and there are disputes sometimes about not being paid overtime, issues with benefits, and not being able to unionise.ldquoSo even before this military protest and the coup, there has been some bad history with the previous government of Aung San Suu Kyi not standing up for workerrsquos rights, Vyas said, adding that because the factories are ownedby China, some protesters view themas part of the cycle that prevents change.Cheap labourVyas describes the cycle as follows: ldquoThe garment workers provide cheap labour to these factories, which helps China grow its influence in Myanmar. Then, Chinarsquos lack of support for protesters bolsters the military regime, which then cracks down on pro-democracy movements.Itrsquos a complicated political situation, one that only adds to the existing challenges of how to operate an ethical trading and supply chain approach that does not appease the junta but does not jeopardise the livelihoods of workers, most of them women who earn as little as , kyata day, the lowest rates in the region.Views dfer on the best approach.Chris Sidoti was part of a UN-ledfact-finding mission which in  urged foreign firms to cut business ties with Myanmarrsquos military over human rights abuses and pursue private sector investments there instead.He sees the situation now as dferent with a military regime in place that has taken over every aspect of government, making it now risky to do any business there. ldquoIf businesses are responsible, they will put everything on hold at this point, Sidoti told Reuters barely a month after the coup, before going on to form an independent advisory group on Myanmar with some other former UN investigators.But, as history has shown, sometimes sanctions hurt more than they help. Previous sanctions on Myanmar have had a humanitarian impact. For example, the US state department estimated that a  US ban on Burmese textile imports cost -, jobs .Given such past experiences, other activist groups today have called for a more nuanced approach, conscious of the economic fragility of Myanmar and the vast poverty that still prevails in much of the country.Long before the coup, Myanmar was widely being described as a ldquofragile state because of its economic uncertainty, institutional dys, and political instability. But the danger now, say some analysts, is that a heavy-handed blanket approach of punitive sanctions could easily turn it into a failed state.A nuanced approach, say observers, is vastly dferent from those expanded sanctions by Western governments targeting the vast network of the Myanmar militaryrsquos economic assets, which are based on two conglomerates: Myanmar Economic Holdings Limitedand Myanmar Economic Corporation .ldquoThe debate over the effectiveness of sanctions is bedevilled by many complex iables, including the objectives of the sanctions and the amount of international compliance, observed veteran journalist, filmmaker and Asia-watcher Tom Fawthrop recently in the online magazine, The DiplomatldquoIn addition, the politics of sanctions could be dferentiated into the good, the bad, and the ugly, Fawthrop added.Limited leverageSome also stress that the international communityrsquos ability to influence developments is finite. ldquoThe outside world has limited leverage, the West in particular, says the ICGrsquos Richard Horsey.ldquoThat doesnrsquot mean the West should sit on its hands and do nothing, but it means their actions will not have a determinative effect on what happens.Horsey told the Financial Times recently: ldquoItrsquos a huge problem for the region, and a problem for the international community ... itrsquos a human catastrophe, and one that has direct implications on Myanmarrsquos neighbours.While government sanctions are one thing the corporate approach could be something  again, say activistsrsquo groups, while insisting that Western brands still need to be rigorous with due diligence as to who they work with.The rights group Burma Campaign UK has called on companies not to abandon Myanmar workers but instead look at ways similar to HMrsquos approach highlighted ndash to maintain placing orders with suppliers albeit under strict scrutiny.John Bray, director at business consultancy Control Risks, said that pressure on firms in Myanmar needed to be guided by an assessment of ldquocomplicity.ldquoIf you are providing a service for the Myanmar people, which they are paid for and which promotes the development of the economy, I donrsquot think yoursquore complicit in what is going on in the streets, said Bray.For the moment there remain some Myanmar union leaders and rights groups that continue to urge clothing chains to stop buying from suppliers in the country to intensy economic pressure on Min Aung Hlaingrsquos junta.But equally there are others who stress that the proceeds from the garment industry for the most part do not go directly into the regimersquos coffers, unlike industries like gemstones, timber, and oil andgas.Many in this latter camp are of the view that what matters more than anything right now is to keep alive structures and jobs outside of the juntarsquos control that will keep people working, eating and afloat.Just how many other clothing companies and retailers make the same decision as HM and Primark, and now resume placing orders with suppliers in Myanmar, remains to be seen.ldquoThe brands feel they have a commitment to the country, and just cutting and running wonrsquot solve anybodyrsquos problems, said Vicky Bowman, director of the Myanmar Centre for Responsible Businessthat advocates for human rights.Itrsquos quite a dilemma, but just how many of us, I wonder, will even pause to give it a thought next time we pick up a garment with a label that says ldquoMade in Myanmar.

story: Boris Johnsonrsquos former top adviser said that when the disease emerged in early , the plan had been to develop resistance in the population in the months leading up to September.In a series of tweets he said that it was only abandoned in early March after Downing Street was warned that it would lead to a ldquocatastrophe.Mr Cummingsrsquo latest intervention comes as he prepares to give evidence on Wednesday to MPs on the Commons health and science committees who are investigating the Governmentrsquos response to the pandemic.  If wed had the right preparations + competent people in charge, we wd probably have avoided lockdown, *definitely* no need for lockdowns . Given the plan was AWOL disaster + awful decisions delayed everything, lockdown became necessarymdash Dominic CummingsMay , Downing Street is braced for a potentially highly damaging onslaught following his acrimonious departure from No  at the end of last year.In a foretaste of what to expect, he said that there may have been no need for any lockdownsthe country hadldquothe right preparations and competent people in charge.Instead he said that at the beginning of March last year, the plan had been ldquoherd immunity and that claims to the contrary by Health Secretary Matt Hancock were ldquobull***t.:Covid Scotland: How many fines have been handed out by policeHe also strongly attacked the media for accepting the Governmentrsquos denials.ldquoMedia generally abysmal on Covid but even Irsquove been surprised by one thing: how many hacks have parroted Hancockrsquos line that lsquoherd immunity wasnrsquot the planrsquo when lsquoherd immunity by Septemberrsquo was lsquoliterally the official plan in all documents graphs meetingsrsquo until it was ditched, he tweeted  Media generally abysmal on covid but even Irsquove been surprised by  thing: how many hacks have parroted Hancockrsquos line that lsquoherd immunity wasnrsquot the planrsquo when herd immunity by Sep was *literally the official plan in all docs graphs meetings* until it was ditchedmdash Dominic CummingsMay , ldquoYes the media is often incompetent but something deeper is at work: much of SWwas happy to believe Hancockrsquos bull***Tthat lsquoitrsquos not the planrsquo so they didnrsquot have to face the shocking truth. title: glasgow-covid-restrictions-eased-week-if-no-increase-icu-admissions
story: Humza Yousaf said the "critical question" is whether infections caused by the new Covid iant "April-" - the so-called Indian iant B.. - lead to more severe disease.Speaking on the BBC Sunday Show, Mr Yousaf said: "The really critical question with the vaccine rollout is: does the new iant lead to more hospitalisations and more severe disease which then requires admission into ICU."If the answer to that is no - and I hope the answer is no - then of course we can look at what we can do in terms of easing restrictions in future."But I promise you, none of us takes any joy from keeping any part of the country under restrictions from a minute longer than necessary.": Covid deaths in under-s outnumber over-s for first time in pandemicMr Yousaf noted that hospital admissions had been increasing in the Greater Glasgow and Clyde region.There were  patients in hospital on Friday with a recent positive test, up from  last Sunday, but only four Covid patients in ICU Scotland-wide.Mr Yousaf said: "What this week will hopefully allow us to do is to see whether we continue to see a rise in hospital admissions but also to see whether that translates into more severe disease that would need admission to ICU. I hope not."The Health Secretary also said he wanted to speed up the vaccine rollout and take a more "proactive" approach to getting people immunised, especially with second doses.A report from Public Health England has shown that the Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines give high protection against infections caused by the Indian iant, but were only % effective against the Indian iant three weeks after the first dose."That enhances the importance of the second dose," said Mr Yousaf."I do believe theres a possibility of maximising our vaccine uptake particularly second doses among those priority groups so although were doing very well with the rollout I think there is scope in the coming weeks to increase the number of vaccines were administering per day, per week."Around % of adults in Glasgow have had both vaccine doses to date.: Dominic Cummings claims minister backed Covid herd immunity planMr Yousaf also defended the decision to keep Glasgow under Level Three restrictions, saying it was a "dficult balance"."I can completely understand why people in Glasgow are feeling somewhat despondent..."The reasons we took those decisions for Glasgow are because we feel they are absolutely necessary, in particular to contain the new iant - the April- iant - of the virus which is thought to be more transmissible andwe control it now it means hopefully we will avoid future lockdowns in the months to come."Mr Yousaf said the "relatively small" number of cases in East Renfrewshire - of around  to  per day - were easier to contain."The dference in East Renfrewshire is that there is not signicant community transmission of the new iant in the way that we see in G, G and some of the southside of Glasgow."Thats really key because the public health officials can contain those relatively small number of cases within those domestic settings."

title: perth-kinross-wildlife-reserve-welcomes-third-osprey-chick
story: The third chick emerged at around pm on Saturday May  at the Scottish Wildle Trustrsquos Loch of the Lowes Wildle Reserve.It joined its older siblings, which hatched on Tuesday and Thursday.This season is the second as a breeding pair for female osprey NCO and male osprey LM after they successfully fledged one chick last year.A Perthshire ranger with the Scottish Wildle Trust, Sara Rasmussen, said: ldquoWe were thrilled to see the chick burst out of its shell.ldquoThere was relatively little notice this one was on the way because part of another eggshell had found its way on to the remaining egg, fitting it like a cap and potentially hiding early signs of hatching.ldquoOspreys gain % of their body weight in the first month of their lives and we can see the youngsters developing almost daily. Itrsquos amazing to think that in around - weeks these tiny chicks will be young birds capable of migrating all the way to Africa.ldquoEven though all of the chicks have hatched, the nest is still vulnerable to disturbance.ldquoOur staff and volunteers, with support from players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery, will continue to keep watch over these amazing birds of prey to ensure they are safe and secure.:Loch of the Lowes: female osprey lays first egg of the seasonPeople can watch the nest on the live osprey webcam.Ospreys were extinct in Britain for much of the th century but began to recover in the s and an estimated  pairs now breed in the UK each summer.The trustrsquos Osprey Protection Programme is supported by players of the Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery.Head of charities at Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery, Laura Chow, said: ldquoItrsquos great to learn that all three eggs have now hatched at Loch of the Lowes.ldquoIrsquom delighted that, thanks to the support from players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery, the ospreys at the reserves are enjoying another successful breeding season. Wersquoll be watching the webcam closely as these young birds develop.

title: lord-advocate-james-wolffe-step-scottish-government-confirms
story: Lord Advocate James Wolffe QC andSolicitor General, Alison Di Rollo QC, have both announced their intention to leave office.Mr Wolffe was appointed in  after his predecessor Frank Mulholland quit the post.His replacement could have a key role in providing legal advice on any future independence referendum legislation.The Lord Advocate has a dual role of heading the prosecution system and, separately, providing legal advice to ministers.Scottish Labour has called for these responsibilities to be split.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: "The Lord Advocate informed the First Minister last year that he intended to leave office following the recent election and confirmed his intention before her re-election by the Scottish Parliament as First Minister."The Solicitor General has confirmed her intention to stand down at the same time.ldquoIt is for the First Minister to nominate new Law Officers and, subject to approval of her nominees by the Scottish Parliament, to recommend their appointment to Her Majesty the Queen."The current Law Officers intend to remain in office until the new Law Officers are appointed."Mr Wolffes role has involved him in controversy in recent months.In February, former first minister Alex Salmond said Mr Wolffe should resign over his role in the Scottish Governments handling of harassment complaints against him.Speaking before a Scottish Parliament inquiry into the affair in March, Mr Wolffe denied any political influence relating to Mr Salmonds criminal prosecution, which ultimately saw him acquitted of  charges at Edinburghs High Court last year.Mr Wolffe told the Holyrood committee: "Any suggestion, from any quarter, that the Crowns decision-making has at any time been influenced by irrelevant considerations or improper motivations would be wholly without foundation."Insinuation and assertions to the contrary are baseless."Mr Wolffe also made a public apology over the wrongful prosecution of two men - before he became Lord Advocate - following a fraud investigation relating to the sale of Rangers.David Whitehouse and Paul Clark had been appointed joint administrators of the club in , but were arrested in  regarding their involvement with the administration.The pair were awarded more than pound million after charges brought against them were dropped or dismissed.The Sunday Times reportedpossible successors to Mr Wolffe could include Laura Dunlop QC, who carried out a review of the Scottish Governments harassment complaint procedures.

title: ron-mckays-diary-former-bbc-boss-tony-halls-appalling-note-forger-martin-bashir-proves-no-right-lord
story: We know now that Bashir lied and fraudulently had created fake bank accounts, seemingly to prove that two people close to her were selling secrets to Rupert Murdochrsquos News International, implicitly The Sun and News Of The World. He used the forgeries to dupe Dianarsquos younger brother Earl Spencer into arranging a meeting with her, and the subsequent TV interview.But more than that, Spencer claims Bashir told him that she was being watched by MI and that there was a plot to kill her. The interview went ahead as we know. Bashirrsquos explanation about why he commissioned the forgeries  He didnrsquot know why he did it. It was ldquostupid. Itrsquos worse than that and it may well be criminal.Tony Hall, then the BBCrsquos head of news and subsequently director-general, sent Bashir a note telling him: ldquoYou should be very proud of your scoop. When doubts were raised about the methods involved he led a whitewash, what the corporation called an inquiry, which totally exonerated Bashir.Spencer was not asked for his side of it, even although Bashir had admitted the forgeries and the brokering of the interview. Hall also misled the BBC board about the circumstances surrounding it. The corporation then, as Lord John Dysonrsquos report into the shoddy affair reveals, instituted a cover-up.In any other news organisation, in any reputable business, when the circumstances of the fraudulent deception were clear, Bashir would have been given  minutes to clear his desk and leave the building. I worked for the BBC when Alasdair Milne was director-general andhe had been in charge hersquod have helped him pack and huckled him out.Bashir resigned from the Beeb days before the report came out, the conclusions of which would have been given to him in advance.Herersquos the rich bit. Since leaving the Beeb, Hall has become the chair of a start-up documentary company called HTYT Stories ndash one of the two directors of which is Godric Smith, a former spokesman for Tony Blair. What an ensemble.Hall is also a le peer ndash Baron Hall of Birkenhead ndash sitting in the House of Lords as a legislator. This is a man, demonstrably in my view, totally unfit to have a seat on the red benches of the most lavishly-decorated room in the Palace of Westminster, to wear the ermine robes or to cast a vote in the governing process.Irsquom currently setting up a petition to have him stripped of the peerage. If it reaches , signatures it will be debated in the Parliament. Details next week.Appy daysTHE Happiness Project. It sounds like a Hollywood movie, or something vaguely religious involving incantations and possibly trepanning, but itrsquos actually a smartphone app which aims to do what it says on the screen. It has been developed by neuroscientists at the University College London with funding from the Medical Research Council and other mental health bodies.There are four games focusing on something scientists feel is important for happiness: uncertainty, thinking about the future, learning, and effort. There are spinning circles, animals and fish with the games asking you for your happiness reaction. It seems a bit simplistic, but then Irsquom not a neuroscientistApparently therersquos something called the ldquohedonic treadmill which is when you donrsquot feel lasting happiness about something good that has happened to you. Perhaps wersquore supposed to feel bad or guilty about this. All I can say is that when I started the games I was in a mellow mood and when I gave up I was angry about the futility of it. That canrsquot be a reaction they were looking for Out of borderLAST month, a Belgian farmer was ploughing a field when he noticed a large stone in his way. So he did what farmers do and threw it out of the way ndash about seven feet away ndash thus redrawing the border between Belgium and France, making his country larger and France smaller. It was a border stone which had been in place since  until the angry farmer expanded his country.This, of course, has ramications for Scottish independence seekers. Those idiots from Scottish Resistance, three men and a mangy cur, could, night after night, move that border sign with England just a few metres north and no-one would notice. After a month or two the unionist-voting Borders would be in England and independence would be a shoo-in.A beautul mindSHE was a bit before my time but Hedy Lamarr was a woman ahead of her own time. She was an Austrian-born, American actress billed by MGM as the most beautul woman in the world. But she was a lot more than that.At the age of  the then-Hedy Kiesler took the leading role in what was a highly-controversial film that would be banned in a number of countries including the US. It was a Czech-made movie called Ecstasy, and in it she played the neglected we of an uncaring older man. What was shocking at the time was that it contained the first scene of an actress, her, having an orgasm. In fact, someone stuck her with a pin, which is a bedroom technique I donrsquot think would work today.She married young ndash well, she married six times and had many flings, including with Howard Hughes. But her first husband, a weapons manufacturer who supplied Mussolini, was domineering, forbidding her to act, so she fled ndash first to Paris and then London where Louis B Mayer, head of MGM, spotted her and signed her up.The important work in her le was as an inventor, principally during the Second World War, when the US had still to enter the war and Britain stood alone. She said of it: ldquoBritish fliers were over hostile territory as soon as they crossed the channel, but German aviators were over friendly territory most of the way to England ... I got the idea for my invention when I tried to think of some way to even the balance for the British. A radio-controlled torpedo, I thought, would do it.rsquoTogether with her friend, the composer and pianist George Antheil, they invented a frequency-hopping device which could not be jammed, as signals could be then. They patented it and took it to the US Navy, who thought it was ldquored hot, but because it came from outside the military and, probably, from a woman, they didnrsquot implement it until .Today, the techniques she invented, called spread spectrum, are used in Bluetooth and wi-fi. Next time I use my mobile Irsquoll be thinking of a truly remarkable woman.

title: mcarthur calls for island proofed covid recovery
story: In the wake of the announcement of a new cabinet secretary for COVID recovery, Orkney MSP Liam McArthur has called for Scotland#s post-pandemic rehabilitation plan to be #island-proofed#.Mr McArthur has joined Shetland MSP Beatrice Wishart in penning a letter to the new cabinet secretary, John Swinney, appealing for the islands to be “front and centre of Scottish Government thinking”.This joint letter comes ahead of a cross party steering group due to be meet next week.The isles MSPs have shared the frustration of many of their constituents who feel that Orkney and Shetland were often seen as an “afterthought” in Scottish Government decision making processes.In the letter, the MSPs pointed to repeated announcements which updated central belt communities while neglecting to mention the dferences in restrictions for the islands.“Throughout the pandemic, there has been a frustration in the communities we represent that island needs have appeared to be an afterthought in Scottish Government decision making processes,# they wrote to Mr Swinney.#Announcements have been made with a wealth of detail about restrictions affecting central belt communities, while failing to include any mention of important dferences for island communities working under dferent rules.“This has often created confusion, not helped by the recent consultation on the easing of restrictions in the islands which was ill-conceived, poorly constructed and the responses ultimately ignored by the government.“As we look ahead to dealing with the impacts of the pandemic and shaping the recovery, it is important that this work fully reflects the islands dimension. We seek assurances, therefore, that  steps will be taken to ensure that this happens. Close collaboration with locally elected representatives, including the island authorities, will be important but we would encourage you and your officials to look at other ways of making sure this happens from the outset.“Needless to say, we would be happy to meet with you to discuss this matter in more detail.  Meantime, we wish you well in the substantial task that lies ahead and stand ready to assist, particularly in ensuring the needs of our islands are front and centre of government thinking.“We look forward to hearing from you in due course.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: road surface dressing delayed by weather
story: newsRoad surface dressing delayed by weatherMay ,  at : pmSurface dressing work which was due to take place in Firth today was postponed due to cold weather, Orkney Islands Council has advised.According to OIC, the work on Holland Road will have to wait until warmer, drier weather s to the county.Surface dressing requires higher road surface temperatures for the materials to bed in properly — something the current cold rainy spell could compromise.The council has advised that, at this stage, the works will be delayed until at least next Tuesday. This will have a knock-on effect on other works planned for that week at Puldrite Road in Rendall, Arwick Road in Evie, Georth Road in Evie, Brough Road in Birsay, Ravie Hill Road in Birsay, and Hundland Road in Birsay.Members of the public affected are advised to check the council website www.orkney.gov.uk news.htm for updates and keep an eye on the the OIC Updates Facebook page.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
